info.title: Where to find system log files?

abstract.para: Kernel messages and messages of system services registered with &systemd; are logged in &systemd; journal (see ). Other system log files are located under the /var/log directory.

topic.para: The following list presents an overview of all system log files from &productname; present after a default installation. Depending on your installation scope, /var/log also contains log files from other services and applications not listed here. Some files and directories described below are placeholders and are only used, when the corresponding application is installed. Most log files are only visible for the user &rootuser;. Usually, you can view these file using an editor as they are in plain text.

important.title: Unsupported log files
important.para:
utmp, wtmp and lastlog have been removed from &productnameshort; and are no longed supported. If there are any applications that writes into these log file, bear in mind that the log files are incomplete then.
wtmp has been replaced with wtmpdb, lastlog with lastlog2.

listitem.para: Logs of the ConsoleKit daemon (daemon for tracking what users are logged in and how they interact with the computer).
Access and error logs of the Common Unix Printing System (cups).
Log files from the Kerberos network authentication system.
Logs from the Network Time Protocol daemon (&chrony;).
libzypp log files. Refer to these files for the package installation history.
Logs from the command line installer zypper.
